item.title: Welcome to #SPHERE Lab

item.description:
Social Computing for Health and Well-being Research Laboratory

Who We Are?

We are a research group in the Department of Biomedical Informatics (DBMI) at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, affiliated with the:

Health Information Privacy Laboratory (IPLab)
Center for Genetic Privacy and Identity in Community Settings (GetPreCise)
AI Discovery & Vigilance to Accelerate Innovation & Clinical Excellence (ADVANCE) Center

Motivation

Our research is motivated by a vast amount of real-world data generated by people/machines in both online and offline environments. We believe that the data, or the evidence hidden in the data, is the key to understanding personal as well as public health and well-being. While new technologies have dramatically changed the world, the nature of social interaction and isolation of human beings is deemed to be a significant factor when decoding such evidence.

Moments

Research is a path we choose, much like any other profession in society—there’s no magic to it. If I had to identify a defining aspect, I’d say we often ‘sacrifice’ our leisure time for what we call freedom in academia—a freedom that feels like we can accomplish anything, but in reality, it often proves to be an illusion. My daughter once said, when she was five, that a worker never stops until midnight. Now, she reminds me, ‘Don’t work hard; work smart.’ That, to me, is true growth. Let’s cherish the moments we’ve shared—laughing, chatting, and engaging in work that we believe can make a difference in the world, no matter how small.

Join Us

We are always on the lookout for passionate and talented individuals to join our team. If you’re excited about innovation and making an impact, we’d love to hear from you!

Open Positions

We may soon have two postdoctoral positions available in Large Language Models. Please stay tuned for more information!

Why Join Us?

  • Innovative Environment: Work on cutting-edge technologies and projects that make a difference.
  • Collaborative Culture: Join a team that values teamwork and creativity.
  • Career Growth: Opportunities for professional development and advancement.

How to Apply

If you’re interested in any of the positions listed above, please send your resume and a brief cover letter to Prof.Zhijun. Make sure to include the position you’re applying for in the subject line.

People

Zhijun Yin

Zhijun Yin, Ph.D., is an Assistant Professor of Biomedical Informatics in the School of Medicine at Vanderbilt University. He is also an Assistant Professor of Computer Science in the School of Engineering. He received his Ph.D. degree in computer science and M.S. degree in biostatistics from Vanderbilt University. Prior to joining this department, he had research internships at Hewlett Packard Labs (focusing on predicting models) and IBM T.J Watson Research Center (focusing on health behavior analytics). He also holds M.E and B.E. degrees in computer science and technology from Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications.

Funded Projects

Prediction of Anti-Cancer Medication Discontinuation via Patient Portal Messages and Structured Electronic Medical Records, R37CA237452

  • Principal Investigator: Zhijun Yin
  • Supporting Agency: NIH/NCI (MERIT Award)
  • Performance Period: 05/01/2020 – 04/30/2026
  • Level of Funding: $2,298,657
  • Goals: In this project, we will analyze the online communications between patients and healthcare providers in a patient portal and apply them as well as structured electronic medical records to predict medication discontinuation.

Note: The Method to Extend Research in Time (MERIT) (R37) Award provides longer-term grant support (up to 7 years) to Early Stage Investigators (ESIs). ESI R01 applications that receive a score within the NCI payline for experienced and new investigators are eligible for consideration to be converted to an ESI MERIT Award. The two-year extension of this award was approved in 05/2024 based on the outstanding performance in the original R01 research.

Publications

1. Social Media and Personal Health Mentions

  • A Scalable Framework to Detect Personal Health Mentions on Twitter
    Journal of Medical Internet Research, 2015.
    A methodology for identifying health-related discussions on Twitter, enhancing understanding of public health conversations.

  • Detecting Personal Health Mentions from Social Media Using Supervised Machine Learning
    Personal Health Informatics, 2022.
    Explores machine learning techniques for identifying personal health discussions in social media, with implications for precision health.
